title: Barksdale-Shaw is a recent doctoral graduate from M ­ ichigan State University with a juris doctorate from the University of ­M ichigan Law School. She considers the impact of legal spaces on literature and how they intervene within early modern culture
She serves as an adjunct professor at Saginaw

container-title: The Journal of the Northern Renaissance, and Eighteenth-­Century ­Fiction
note: She co-edited Topographies of the Imagination: New ­Approaches to Defoe (AMS Press, 2014) and Digital Defoe: Studies in Defoe & His Contemporaries.
title: Katherine Ellison is a Professor of English at Illinois State University and author of A Cultural History of Early Modern English ­Cryptography Manuals (Ashgate/Routledge, 2016) and Fatal News: Reading and Information Overload in Early Eighteenth-Century Literature ­(Routledge, 2006) as well as several articles on early cryptography in The Journal of Early Modern Cultural Studies, Book History

container-title: The Changing Identity of Medieval Music (Cambridge, 2004) and Music in Films on the Middle Ages: ­Authenticity vs
note: Fantasy (Routledge, 2013). He is a contributor most recently to The Cambridge Companion to French Music (2015) and The Oxford Handbook of Victorian Medievalism (forthcoming).
title: John Haines is a Professor of Music and Medieval Studies at the ­University of Toronto. He has published on medieval and Renaissance music and its modern reception in a variety of journals, both musicological—from Early Music History to Popular Music—and non-­musicological—from Romania to Scriptorium. His books include Eight Centuries of ­Troubadours and Trouvères
Harris is a Professor of Old English and Germanic philology at the University of Massachusetts and author most recently of Bede and Aethelthryth: An Introduction to Christian Latin Poetics
He regularly teaches a course on the history of cryptography
Susan Kim is a Professor of English at Illinois State University, specializing in Old English literature
